awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Rewilding, Wildlife Conservation Decision-Making, and Environmental Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Protecting the habitats for threatened or endangered wildlife in national parks and reserves has been a long-standing practice of wildlife conservation. However, the effects of climate change on these protected habitats demands a reconsideration of whether or not this model is effective. Recent scholarship has suggested that the conservation methodology of rewilding – the reintroduction or stabilization of wildlife populations as a way to restore ecosystems – provides an alternative. Its emphasis on dispersing wildlife through corridors might provide species with greater flexibility to migrate within and between warming ecosystems. This research examines the implementation of rewilding projects to assess how the effects of climate change on wildlife habitats influence scientific practices on the ground. In addition to training a doctoral student in ethnographic methods and analysis, this research should provide evidence of how conservation scientists and practitioners confront the reality of changing climates in their efforts to prevent extirpation and extinction. Research findings will be shared with conservation organizations (non-governmental and governmental) and will be published in both academic and non-academic avenues in order to raise public awareness regarding the seriousness of climate change for threatened wildlife.   

The central question of this project asks whether, how, and why climate change informs stakeholder responses to and decisions about wildlife conservation. To answer this, research will be conducted among several groups of stakeholders including conservation philanthropists, scientists, state officials, and local communities. By integrating perspectives from actors involved in or affected by rewilding projects, this research tests for the cultural, economic, scientific, and/or political concerns that guide conservation decision-making. This research brings together frameworks from Science Studies and political ecology to provide new theoretical insights into how recourse to scientific expertise, political power, and economic influence inflects climate change responses. Through employing ethnographic methods like participant observation and in-depth interviews, this project demonstrates the importance of anthropological investigation in climate change research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This doctoral research examines large-scale rewilding initiatives in the Chilean Patagonia, investigating rewilding as a conservation methodology, a discursive project, a philanthropic strategy, a territorial reordering, and a holistic vision to counter both extinction and climate change. Funded by NSF’s DDRIG in Cultural Anthropology, the Co-PI spent 10 months carrying out research in and around Parque Nacional Patagonia. Prior to its purchase by US conservationists, the park was a working estancia providing both economic and cultural value to nearby residents. Conservation initiatives have utilized rewilding – the reintroduction or stabilization of native wildlife – to restore the ecosystem from the purported damages caused by ranching operations, prompting a sense of historical erasure among some residents owing to this ecological, social, and material transition. However, early findings suggest that much of the rewilding initiatives rely on the same logics of production of the ranching estancia prior to the purchase by conservationists, in fact elucidating the cultural and historical apparatus that underlies such conservation efforts. Further preliminary findings drawn from close ethnographic investigation of species rewilding projects within the national park (huemul deer, condor, Darwin’s rhea, puma, guanaco) reflect the novel and uncertain methods behind the science of rewilding, producing forms of disagreement among state and nongovernmental actors involved in wildlife conservation. Lastly, early results suggest that rewilding’s new application as a tool to fight climate change demonstrates the role of philanthropy in changing the discourses of the weight, necessity, and purpose of both landscape and wildlife conservation. The Co-PI’s incipient theoretical framework will mutually engage rewilding’s practices and pragmatics and rewilding’s logic of property, allowing articulated discussions from science studies and political economy/ecology. 

The purchases by US conservationists within the Chilean Patagonia reflects the shifting schema of land ownership in the region, leading this research to inquire into the larger processes of property buy-up and concomitant land use change. As part of this line of inquiry, the co-PI has developed a secondary project with community members analyzing how changing property structures is affecting access and use of local water resources. Alongside a local organization, the Co-PI has submitted a project proposal for funds to carry out collaborative research into the management of the town of Cochrane’s river basin. Thus, the exploration of territorial transformation generated by the empirical focus on rewilding has proven applicable to investigate other questions of local environmental management beyond conservation, a key outcome for this project. This new collaborative project will involve local high school students as principal investigators, aiming to inspire curiosity in students of the interplay between environmental and social worlds and so incite students to become researchers of their own territory. 

The Co-PI was able to use funds from NSF to hire a recently graduated Chilean anthropology student as a research assistant, providing valuable training and experience to early career anthropology students. Furthermore, the Co-PI has carried out one presentation with another upcoming of early findings at two Chilean universities. Further presentations with local community members, state bureaucracies, and conservation organizations will be planned for return trips once data is analyzed and findings are clear. Upon completion of data analysis, the Co-PI plans to organize and present results for two key project outcomes. The first outcome entails an in-depth exploration of rewilding as a practice, inquiring into the methodology’s relationship to climate change, relevant in conversation with conservation practitioners, financers, and proponents of nature-based solutions to climate change. Second, the results from the Co-PI’s investigation of conservation philanthropy will be utilized to analyze public-private partnerships and accordingly consolidate information on strengthening these ongoing initiatives.
